iati-activity.title: Strengthen Lib Capability to provide climate info & Serv
iati-activity.description: It will support current climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia so as to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.

iati-activity.title: Strengthen Lib Capability to p
iati-activity.description: Strengthen climate monitoring and Early Warning Systems in Liberia to increase adaptive capacity of local communities and sectors.

Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen Liberia’s climate-related monitoring capabilities, early warning systems and available information for responding to climate shocks and planning adaptation to climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Capacity as per capacity assessment scorecard.
2. Domestic finance committed to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

baseline.comment:
1. Average capacity scorecard rating of 57 across men and women (see Annex 5).
2. Annual budget of US$ 64,480 allocated to Meteorology Department; annual budget of US$ 276,877 allocated to Hydrological Services; and annual budget of US$50,000 allocated to NDRC.

target.comment:
1. Capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 134 for both men and women (see Annex 5).
2. 20% increase in annual domestic finance allocated to Meteorology Department, Hydrological Services and NDRC to monitor and warn against extreme weather and climate change.

actual.comment: Under the reporting period, there has been no increase in domestic finance to monitor and warn against climate hazards. However, we are optimistic that the awareness being generated about the importance of early warnings for the operations of different sectors and when alerts and warnings begin to be issued from the EWS Project and National Meteorological and Hydrological Services (NMHS), all this will prove the need for public finance and financing from private sources, such as the sales of weather products. The first year of implementation has been mired by the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease which slowed down several aspects of implementation, especially field-based activities and those involving collaboration with partners and external consultants.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Increased capacity of hydro-meteorological services and associated networks to monitor and predict extreme weather, climate-related hazards and climate trends.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Percentage of national coverage of climate monitoring network (fully operational).
2. Frequency of data transmission.
3. Number of sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced using improved information.

baseline.comment:
1. AWS: 0%
Hydrometric stations: 0%.
2. At present, the 1 AWS transmits data at the synoptic hours of (GMT) 06h00, 09h00, 12h00, 15h00, 18h00 and 00h00, although not consistently.
3. At present, the only sector-specific information produced is for the aviation sector.

target.comment:
1. AWS: 100% (at least 9 AWSs).
Hyrdometric: 100% (at least 6 stations).
2. 18 AWSs and hydrometric stations (11 new AWSs, 1 rehabilitated AWS, 6 hydrometric stations), transmitting continuously.
3. Sector-specific, tailored climate information packages produced for three of the following: agriculture, water, aviation, fisheries/coastal water users, health, tourism, construction, energy and road, rail and sea transport.

actual.comment: Core activities around this output could not be implemented due to the outbreak of the Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) and the subsequent delays in the procurement of equipment and services. The Government of Liberia requested UNDP to procure equipment along with services like training, installation and maintenance. Because of the low level of human capital, we feel that the procurement of equipment alone cannot guarantee EWS for Liberia and its long term sustainability. The long term agreement (LTA) to be issued by CIRDA is the best option for the country. The EVD also hampered other capacity building activities as experts could not come into the country and staff could not be accepted in several countries for training. In 2014, negotiations with the World Meteorological Organization Training Institutions in Nigeria and Kenya collapsed because of the EVD, but responses from both countries are advanced and students will be sent over by 4th quarter. Probably the most substantive deliverable for the year, besides training, will be the renovation of the building to be used as the National Meteorological Center (NMC) within the premises of the Roberts International Airport. This project is to begin during the 4th quarter.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Efficient and effective use of tailored climate, environmental and socio-economic data to produce appropriate information which can be communicated to government entities and communities to enable informed decision-making.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. Number of communication channels operational to disseminate climate-related early warnings.
2. Percentage of population within the two targeted districts that has access to improved climate-related flood, storm and coastal surge warnings (disaggregated by gender).

baseline.comment:
1. At present, information is relayed to communities mostly via word-of-mouth, but without the structure of SOPs.
2. 0% of men
0 % of women.

target.comment:
1. At least 3 of the following: radio, television, print media (newspapers, flyers), word-of-mouth and mobile phone communication channels are operational.
2. 100 % of men
100 % of women.

actual.comment: These activities were delayed until equipment is procured, deployed and climate information is generated to be communicated to target users. There is no product to communicate at this stage.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Increased awareness in government, private sector and local communities of the major risks associated with climate change, and use of available information when formulating development policies and strategies.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Development frameworks that integrate climate information in their formulation.

baseline.comment: 1. The Agenda for Transformation (2012-2017) highlights the need to develop climate change mainstreaming and response strategies, but does not emphasize the need for improved information to inform the strategies.

target.comment: 1. At least updated Agenda for Transformation (to be revised in 2017) to incorporate the availability of climate information into planning for the five year period.

actual.comment: The ongoing collaboration with the Ministry of Finance and Development Planning around the EWS Project implementation and other fora organized by other NAPA and National Projects as well as the UNDP will guarantee an entry point for the revision of the AfT when the time comes. The MFDP leads the process of developing the Nation's development agenda and is a member of the Project Steering Committee. The EWS is making inputs into the development of the National Adaptation Plan (NAP) for Liberia and is poised to integrate climate information into national and sectorial plans.
